C279A317CCDE41CCBAD9E5FF26B7C00E.description: Construct an improved product based on design cycle.

80B82C92448C4ED9AEE75550ADD9B11F.description: Gather feedback or critique of the model or prototype

84E2389497D848FFADEB0DA807AF5466.description: Design and construct a model or prototype of an improved product.

DD594894BDD04BB3BB43BA50D789D2A0.description: Gather feedback or critique from focus group or end user.

99B7E2696F1E486CA4B34A46349FDA65.description: Sketch a model of the improved design.

B9C600BCDB014353A3B70A80928558C3.description: Gather user feedback on nature of improvements required in design.

2B63005DC5454775AA65149998AAAEA3.description: Select a product to be improved.

77855DE7DEA3438590BCC86751451689.description: Design and construct a project applying concepts of design studies.

DB3F25234C7E4101A4652E8C686E54EC.description: Assess how gathering feedback on models and prototypes and the process of critique and reflection helps improve an overall design.

50D558E0152A423E8D0C5939101FA2B3.description: Write a critique of a design with an explanation of how to improve the quality of the final product.

B43A7CD0FFD8472F9657C5DD7E302BC2.description: Offer and accept feedback, constructively and effectively, to improve a design.

BC3937475B954FECBE14CD060ACE7834.description: Critique design solutions using a process that includes the following stages: Describe: What do you see (e.g., colour, shape, form)? Analyze: What did the producer intend? Interpret: Is the product successful in conveying the message or achieving its purpose? Is the product successful using elements and principles of visual design? and, Evaluate: What changes would I suggest? What factors need to be considered in assessing the feasibility of the potential changes?

C1407BFF5FE140A9A6151B2EA4B5A78D.description: Differentiate between constructive and nonconstructive criticism.

71C9F2B6BD5E410CA7D6932925CACA54.description: Identify criteria for desired characteristics or results for a product or process.

9A5FCCE4CCA64B3EA04B19AE12F48C6D.description: Examine methods of critique for both individual and collaborative design processes.

6E4B98AD1EB64CEC94B63F8755E4E3B4.description: Identify potential sources of critique for improvement, emphasizing the importance of communication with the end user or client as essential to the work of professional designers.

68B6CDC9873C4F3DA3B22A0923A2B5D2.description: Create norms for assessing work and providing feedback in a respectful and professional manner

AF33C42CC1E64D0796DFF4530E2667D2.description: Critique proposed design solutions to improve overall design.

4C5E9F79D10C49F4989422E2EBAB3BE0.description: Assess graphic design products and software and justify the rationale for personal design choices.

ACBA79047407498ABFEF07F09AFC9A31.description: Co-develop and use of assessment devices such as rubrics and checklists to assess graphic designs.

334026769ED34BE8A38FB16D12F7D082.description: Solve a graphic design challenge, adhering to applicable copyright permissions and restrictions.

7B609B7C030E401F9E6AEE2A82CC6985.description: Experiment with basic tools used to create graphic designs, such as graphic design software, photo manipulation software, layout software, vector graphic software, card stock, cutting tools and artistic mediums (e.g., paints, charcoal, ink, chalk).

24BDE2FD0A1943D39A7566AA030F56AD.description: Manipulate typography to create various effects in communication.

F46D874B34CA4C9F8962C0233ED7735D.description: Research fundamental aspects of typography such as line length, type size and leading (i.e., space between lines of text).

369D8E2396854E5DA9FD200639B67D36.description: Demonstrate elements and principles of design in a graphic design challenge, including: scale and proportion;  typography;  layout; and, colour

066476D048A34A629F1204DEF87D14BE.description: Apply the elements and principles of graphic design in a two-dimensional creation, such as a webpage, logo or advertisement.

2E84935AA7C6408E80B45AB5D01FDB92.description: Identify the purpose of graphic design as a form of communication with an audience.

FBE4813589BC410BB67ED5615A4DFCBA.description: Create a twodimensional graphic representation using the elements and principles of design.

AECF2CF22CA345728DB3D78FC6891C24.description: Explain how different forms of three-dimensional sketching such as orthographic, isometric or cantilevered drawing help change perspective of the product.

CD32FAEF1981492AAAF0FB453B319F5A.description: Sketch simple two-dimensional geometric figures and shapes, orthographic drawings, isometric drawings (30o and 60o ) and pictorial drawings that demonstrate layout, proportion, accuracy and neatness.

BDEC806482944C2BA92426E4AFFC66D9.description: Identify drawings of geometric forms such as two-dimensional geometric figures, orthographic form and pictorial form.

15C7BE8E6C604434849F6D91DB4D051E.description: Create a freehand sketch and shade of a manufactured form (e.g., shoe).

99F0C8A801EB4BE8A754A51E0982FABF.description: Create a freehand sketch and shade of a natural form (e.g., a log, an apple).

CE826F5760DA4CEEB9C6C37674B0032D.description: Apply elements of sketching to a design challenge, including: line; shape; form; colour; space; texture; and, value.

305683162DAA4BCCA65F1170EB3A8CCC.description: Apply the skill of drawing to scale on a design challenge.

D6C5DC14E51A4561B76AF7B252E19664.description: Investigate line theory as it applies to sketching.

307743DDBA87420F8ACD807D7C10D821.description: Select the best medium for sketching in the context of a design challenge.

132B54246CEE4235991893AC8A57F92F.description: Identify types of media available for sketching, including soft media (e.g., pencil, charcoal, crayons, pastels), hard media (e.g., marker), and wet media (e.g., ink applied with a brush, paint).

C9136C2D70CC4CE3BEE928B6FCD16FA0.description: Describe the purpose of creating sketches at the preliminary stages of a design process.

A44CB7B0A2C9442E81A6E414D3C2B8C1.description: Create free hand sketches demonstrating layout and proportion to illustrate ideas and support design processes.

608141715C1D497B9FB7DF141719ECA6.description: Evaluate the extent to which a model is an accurate representation and aesthetically pleasing.

2671B39EB4A34C0FA80C82D0DCB368DD.description: Present models to peers or end users (clients) for feedback and to ensure both designer and end user have the same understanding of the design challenge being addressed.

D991C11C485D4E55952AFF20919A365D.description: Create a prototype to illustrate how various visual elements of design are used in model making.

483CAB5620AA4138B21B70B562689656.description: Differentiate between geometric and free-form styles of three-dimensional models.

075D21E2759E40EFA6C1AE2155132F0A.description: Use virtual spaces to create prototypes and models of designs.

CB7B522000354943B697121C4C4FF06D.description: Investigate various reasons and purposes for modelling in the design process.

61C52531C96643A4AB8C3BDCF77F7B34.description: Construct a model that focuses on form.

A919ECABB58E4DF48FDB2F9CC4BDEBB5.description: Speculate how differing cultural contexts can change the way that certain aesthetic features are perceived (e.g., clothing, universal design norms).

4CA9EE9ACE184F18AA0E3F501BBB4251.description: Explore how form impacts the way we interact with a product, leading to preference of one product over another (e.g., clothing, washroom fixtures).

BDD7448446AC46198A5B700DBEF45CF0.description: Describe how the aesthetic choices of form can detract from or enhance the functionality of a variety of products (e.g., a convertible rooftop on a car may look attractive but is not functional to heat the interior of the car in cold temperatures).

402C0CE85ECF40879186FD5F65DBB5D4.description: Identify a variety of products that share a function but use a variety of aesthetic choices, such as colour, shape, size and surf

3906ABFB7BD44658A90103A27DB964F7.description: Explore alternative materials and processes that might be used in creating a product.

D5A74C66743741C2AE0B41E4694E9ED4.description: Explore the impacts of aesthetics and function on the human psyche.

C30A2A0E9041469298EF0632C512AA80.description: Assess the aesthetic choices used to convey the intended functionality of a variety of products.

041293E0471D4C778EB87966F317E704.description: Identify the relationship between function and aesthetics, and function and form.

8947713DE255468B9C20F8B3130AE690.description: Define aesthetics (i.e., that which is considered beautiful or tasteful), form (i.e., an objectâ€™s shape, size and material from which it is made), and function (i.e., the purpose of an object or what it helps people do) as they relate to design.

06DB7A4569EB492CAB92C1FA636AF3E3.description: Investigate the relationship between aesthetics and function in design.

CBF1496F861443F3AA1098DD49786ABB.description: Design and test a product improvement plan using current manufacturing processes.

4664E0A2E17E4C33B7F82B04477B26A5.description: Summarize how each step of the design process is engaged in the improvement of a product or procedure.

AE5DD45F4B21474E8E7816C5F7ADA49E.description: Review a variety of methods to gather data regarding the needs and requirements of a client (e.g., survey customers/stakeholders, explore marketplace for current solutions and trends) for a design improvement.

0D2AE9F59A2C4A7382B4F8B8BE07FA97.description: Identify modifications to improve a current design.

5D5197F7B87E4961A419497B88C1F704.description: Determine what problems or opportunities for modification exist to improve or broaden the application of products or procedures to achieve a desired outcome.

1711527D8A5D40809215BF7E5A0F132F.description: Hypothesize why decisions regarding form and function were made in the original design process.

EC4492175EB141E2979590F16441527F.description: Examine existing products (e.g., a pencil, a pen, a backpack) or procedures (e.g., the process of moving from classroom to classroom for various classes, the process for borrowing library books) and critically evaluate their form, function(s) and limitations, including universal design considerations.

43DA0F86147840609612AA1AD7332458.description: Analyze the design process in a design improvement scenario.

D6869F5CBA124FEF98F8242E0EE6B9CD.description: Explain why universal design is important to include in all spaces, not just industrial, commercial or publicly accessed buildings and spaces.

73FE0B8F1C0B4654A2174C21E198CB67.description: Suggest considerations required in the design process to develop products and places that are accessible to people with a wide range of abilities, to the greatest extent possible.

BBC9EA1DD3304320A7211C057EC7CADE.description: Propose universal design improvements that would enhance user experiences with a variety of private and public spaces and products.

E09BE8926E204C20AEDB84E3DE7790C0.description: Explore the benefits of universal design applications such as levered doorknobs, taps in sinks and tubs, strategically placed assisted lifts and grab bars, governors on water heaters, adjustable height cupboards and tables, no barrier entries to buildings in single family dwellings and multiunit residential dwellings

6B95896873DD48E3BAA86B69B0C3608B.description: Create an inventory of universal design features in school and community spaces.

4D9D065447EC497CB12D43BDB225C91B.description: Describe ways in which universal design is beneficial to all individuals regardless of life stage or physical abilities.

3DE4E440937E4492B806FC7A92C5AFD0.description: Explain how universal design facilitates empowerment and self sufficiency among individuals and organizations encountering designed spaces, objects or events

78AA48CB3B974FB1A0FC2254A5757542.description: Examine ethical and economic reasons for inclusion of universal design in all design processes.

A17E81F98596499CBA27F2D064755235.description: Identify individuals, groups and organizations that have advocated for change in design thinking and individual and systemic dispositions toward design.

2BEAEC89591C4CFF9366A6538296BBAD.description: Research ways in which design has resulted in exclusion of individuals from accessing objects or spaces.

7F5EF39CC56740FE96818134A675D93F.description: Differentiate between user-centred design and universal design.

574A444FF11945E5BB3125CC4CBCABEE.description: Investigate the accessibility principles of universal design, including: equitable use; flexibility in use; simple and intuitive use; presence of perceptible information; tolerance for error;  low physical effort; and, size and space for approach and use.

C21DD63B25DE49D4959D3687FD3481D0.description: Assess the importance and value of universal design in designing products and spaces.

DC23215E4F9C4783B1FF62D1D473DFCA.description: Reflect on the solutions to problems in a journal or portfolio.

1A28DEEF3CAB476EBE2B72BCE13C9810.description: Plan a presentation illustrating solutions to architecture and interior design challenges.

D066A9D8FEED445FBD8D734A4C0DEF47.description: Assess the potential solutions to challenges and document the deliberation.

D4A820D2AA0246B4B9854F3B5D75BEAD.description: Create solutions to a given architectural design challenge, using the principles and elements of the design process.

337F11BBA4874BD08EF5FD35F486E5B9.description: Discuss the interrelationship of elements of architecture and interior design

6F8E9B3176B244C189BE6DBC0F63EC6D.description: Describe the components of the design process in an architectural situation, including: form; place/location; flow/connection; and, materials

9C3A970A1B8F4A73878D705D0CC2CD3B.description: Apply the design process in designing a three-dimensional space.

7856946CC3894FBDA5E417390C3C0423.description: Design Fundamentals - Architecture and Interior Design (Core)

8DEF83C70250468FBD8A971B5A369BB1.description: Apply the creative design process to an aesthetic challenge scenario.

2033BEE1479145B6917565277001EAF1.description: Develop a visual representation illustrating the creative design process.

3453998C0A7449B69D635CF3E3045DF7.description: Justify the importance of both the process and the final product in artistic design decisions.

413D6BEFAA384148B38E6078B87D53B0.description: Compare the characteristics of artistic, manufacturing and engineering design processes.

218BE258B2694DB99E3A60BDAF52533C.description: Explain the relationship between art and creative design.

0B160AAD0FA64E25939DBA05CD363B78.description: Explore the steps of a creative design process, including: define the problem to be addressed; collect information pertinent to the problem from an end user (or client if design is commissioned); brainstorm potential approaches and solutions; analyze ideas and assess ideas and potential solutions; develop potential solutions; test potential solutions and/or present ideas for feedback to end user, client, design expert or peers; collect data from test of potential solutions; improve tested solution; improve design; and, communicate with end user regarding the effectiveness of a design and address further modifications desired.

712274AEAE8A415D935E57042E55340F.description: Investigate the steps in a creative design process.

1B2408B1B37C459E851EF4C83BCB338A.description: Create a visual representation and narrative description of the engineering design process.

5AAACD6997414CD49008DE83AF245746.description: Elicit feedback using the appropriate terminology from the design process.

4987309F5E164CFDA57CA35EC62AEFFC.description: Apply the design process to an engineering challenge scenario, such as building a tower with limited materials or building a bridge to hold maximum weight with minimum material.

9B67EA01B1AC4804AA9847632EA53556.description: Differentiate between types of engineering challenges to be solved, including structural, mechanical, electrical and systems engineering.

8B9EB48B98414D9BA93321A17096CC80.description: Explore the steps of an engineering design process: define the problem to be addressed; collect information pertinent to the problem; brainstorm potential approaches and solutions; analyze ideas and assess ideas and potential solutions; develop potential solutions; test potential solutions and gather data regarding success or aspects for further improvement or refinement; refine or modify design; test refinement or modification; collect data from test of potential solutions; improve tested solution; and, improve design.

C732960DEFD04972BC9DE7C28AE6EC8C.description: Differentiate among processes for designing: a product for personal use (e.g., snowboard, hair dryer, backpack); a system (e.g., computer or transportation network, supply chain); and, an industrial process (e.g., power generating station, water treatment plant).

A65F890596A44486AA4DA274150573A9.description: Elicit feedback for a prototype using the terminology of the design process.

02D6CEF31310435DAAF5F7D39C210EA8.description: Adapt and refine the design to reflect data gleaned from the testing of prototypes.

BB897957E8E9492CAFFE9A9CBCB5D935.description: Critically evaluate the efficacy of design decisions made within the prototype.

F0F5504CF51442D38243684C7B5EFBED.description: Create a prototype from a given scenario to illustrate a design process, including: an annotated sketch of a solution to a design problem; two-dimensional and three-dimensional models of the solution to the design problem using digital tools; and, a variety of prototypes to test different elements within the design.

0026DA5C397C441EB963004FF07EFF4C.description: Speculate on reasons for creating either a comprehensive prototype (e.g., similar in appearance and including most components and attributes of a final product), or a focused prototype (e.g., implementing and testing one or two components and attributes of a final product).

DBFD4F6FA5254CA5B2324F992AE79067.description: Describe the benefits of various forms of prototypes, including: concept sketches; mathematical models; simulations; component parts of a product; and, fully functional preproduction versions of a product.

63A9FF0F1745408BB90FD58E8BFB08DA.description: Differentiate between a physical and an analytical prototype.

68F3BDDD20C548B6BF1EC0928748C5E5.description: Describe situations in which either a model or a prototype is an important aspect of the design process.

63A07B28D5F4454885691B9068EEBF0A.description: Identify critical attributes that differentiate a prototype from a model.

3503E488A35A4FBC9D5CF682FF7BD986.description: Define the term model and explain the purpose for modelling in the design process.

A745FEAF2DD1402B83709F0E1431953D.description: Define the term prototype and explain various purposes for design prototyping, including: learning (e.g., Does it work? Does it meet the intended need?); communication (e.g., the prototype helps others, such as investors or managers to understand, appreciate and support further development.); integration (i.e., Do all the individual components and systems work when integrated together?); and, illustrating milestones.

6E1A5867A6554D0AA568D73F9EA310AA.description: Investigate the role of modelling and prototyping in the design process.

24A9EF369DF5487F87A9753CF9108ABC.description: Investigate how designers apply the elements of design, using the principles of design.

5018DC43771B4E4AB63FA4993345A13D.description: Describe common principles of design, including: balance; proportion; scale; rhythm; emphasis; contrast; unity; and, harmony.

A5DB961BF9C9460D8611AC037DF0E10A.description: Identify common elements of design, including: line; form; space; texture; light; colour; type; value; and, pattern.

C4D3781FADF1436A9FF98E5A2013069E.description: Explore common principles and elements of design.

26DC690849D8440B9C67049B6F1778CE.description: Apply the steps of the design process to a simple design challenge.

31D7FB078A6B4C48B8ABE9038E7DCA04.description: Create a visual representation (e.g., flow chart, concept map, story board) of the stages of a design process.

0F43128BC8F74B79A1A57FBE44097BBC.description: Examine how the design process is non-linear and recursive, and includes: communication of the problem or need by the end user to the designer; and, clarification of perception of end user expectation by the designer; or need held by the designer; provided (i.e., test, refine and improve, test again).

E8E979C4E8BA49C297C3177B303958D6.description: Identify the steps of the design process, including: define the problem, challenge or need to be addressed; collect information pertinent to the problem, challenge or need;brainstorm potential approaches and solutions; analyze and assess ideas and potential solutions; develop potential solutions; test potential solutions and/or present ideas for feedback; collect data from test of potential solutions; refine and improve tested solution; and, test, refine and improve the design

FE4BAE2B1A304900BA125F4A277F87D4.description: Describe the various categories or branches of the study of design, including: consumer product design; textile and fashion design; â€¢ architectural and interior design; garden and landscape design; capital product design; systems and network design; graphic design (e.g., branding, corporate identity); environmental design; software and interface design; industrial design; and, urban design (community planning)

54D3F64A37894DAB93E501D15677A02C.description: Explore design studies and the stages of a design process.
